description: Stories must capture discrete behavior that can be described in system or business terms. Each story represents a distinct behavioral unit — not raw data access or isolated operations, but a recognizable action with a describable outcome.

do.description: Create stories that capture discrete behavior describable in system/business terms. Example: 'User --> load story graph' (behavior: retrieve and display story structure)

guidance.description: Each story must represent a discrete behavior — a recognizable action that can be described in business or system terms. Order by user journey flow, not technical sequence. The test: can you describe what this story DOES as a behavior someone would recognize? If yes, it's a valid story.
example: User --> load story graph (behavior: retrieve and display story structure)
Developer --> edit epic name (behavior: modify story map element)
User --> generate DrawIO diagram (behavior: produce visual diagram output)
System --> initialize configuration on startup (behavior: prepare system for use)
System --> display recipient bank details (behavior: show bank information after recipient selection)

dont.description: Don't create stories that are raw data operations with no describable behavior. Example: 'System --> read all epics from diagram' (no behavior - just data access, what happens next?)

guidance.description: Don't create raw data access operations that lack describable behavior — these are implementation steps, not stories
example: System --> read all epics from diagram (no behavior - just data access, then what?)
System --> load all features in graph epic (no describable outcome)
System --> serialize components to JSON (implementation step, not behavior)
System --> convert diagram to StoryGraph format (data transformation, not behavior)
System --> calculate component positions (computation, not behavior)

guidance.description: Don't create stories too large to describe as a single behavior - split into discrete behavioral units
example: User --> manage entire order lifecycle (multiple behaviors bundled - split)
System --> process complete checkout workflow (multiple behaviors bundled - split)

guidance.description: Don't order stories by technical sequence instead of user journey flow - stories should follow the user's journey, not implementation order
No-behavior indicators to reject - these patterns indicate stories lack describable behavior
example: Just reads/loads data without describable outcome
Just converts/formats data as an implementation step
Just calculates/computes as an intermediate operation
